SubTopics: Divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.
Content: Divide: 18 ÷ 1/12

Key.Rationale: Inverts both 18 and 1/12 before multiplying (or divided 12 by 18).
Divides 18 by 12.
Inverts 1/12 but then adds 12 to 18.
Correct.

SubTopics: Demonstrate an understanding that in a multi-digit number, a digit in one place represents 1/10 of what it represents in the place to its left.
Content: Joe writes a number with a 3 in the tenths place. Ellie also writes a number with a 3 as a digit. The value of the 3 in Ellie’s number is 10 times the value of the 3 in Joe’s number. Which number could be the one Ellie wrote?

Key.Rationale: Uses the tens place instead of the tenths place for the 3 in Joe’s number.
Correct.
Identifies a number that could be Joe’s number.
Identifies a number using a 3 that is }1 of the value of the 3 in Joe’s number 10 instead of 10 times the value.

SubTopics: Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place using >, =, and < symbols.
Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, word form, and expanded form.
Content: An inequality is shown below.
Which number could be placed into the blank to make the inequality true?

Key.Rationale: Correct.
Compares 27 to 20.

C.Choice: four and two hundred five thousandths

Key.Rationale: Selects an equal amount.

D.Choice: four and two hundred four thousandths

Key.Rationale: Compares the numbers in the wrong direction.

SubTopics: Multiply multi-digit whole numbers (not to exceed three-digit by three-digit).
Find whole-number quotients of whole numbers with up to four-digit dividends and two-digit divisors.
Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths (no divisors with decimals).
Content: A number is multiplied by 4, then divided by 2, and finally multiplied by 0.5. How does the result compare to the original number?

A.Choice: The result is the same as the original number.

Key.Rationale: Correct.

B.Choice: The result is four times the value of the original number.

Key.Rationale: Thinks the second and third operations “cancel” each other OR finds n × 4 × 2 × 0.5 OR finds n × 4 ÷ 2 ÷ 0.5.

C.Choice: The result is one-fourth the value of the original number.

Key.Rationale: Finds n ÷ 4 × 2 × 0.5.

D.Choice: The result cannot be compared to the original number without knowing the original number.

Key.Rationale: Does not understand how the operations are related.

SubTopics: Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions.
Content: The expression below shows two fractions being added.
Which expression could be used to find the sum of the two fractions?

Key.Rationale: Decomposes numerators and denominators in attempt to get a common denominator.
Adds numerators and adds denominators in original fractions.
Correct.
Does not notice that 1/72 should be 2/72.

SubTopics: Solve addition and subtraction problems involving fractions (straight computation or word problems).
Content: Priya has two pieces of fabric.
• One piece is 8/12 foot in length.
• The other piece is 3/12 foot in length.
Priya uses 9/12 foot of the fabric to make a pillowcase. How many feet of fabric does Priya have remaining?

Key.Rationale: Correct.
Finds total length of fabric before making pillowcase.

SubTopics: Add and subtract fractions (including mixed numbers) with unlike denominators. (May include multiple methods and representations.)
Content: Tanya makes a paper volcano in science class. She spends 1/3 hour building the base, 1/6 hour shaping the cone, and 1/8 hour painting the outside. How many hours does Tanya spend making the volcano?

Key.Rationale: Adds numerators (before conversion), but uses correct LCD and reduces.
Adds numerators (before conversion), then denominators (before conversion).
Correct.
Adds numerators correctly (following conversion); adds denominators (before conversion).

SubTopics: Solve multiplication and division problems involving fractions and whole numbers (straight computation or word problems).
Content: Cereal boxes are arranged on three different shelves in a grocery store.
• The top shelf is 42 1/2 inches in length and 14 2/5 inches in width.
• The middle shelf is 1 2/5 times the length of the top shelf and 1 1/2 times the width of the top shelf.
• The bottom shelf is 4/5 times the length of the middle shelf and 3/4 times the width of the middle shelf.
What are the length and the width of the bottom shelf?

Key.Rationale: Calculates the correct length but subtracts the sum of “times the width” fractions of the middle and bottom shelves from the width of the top shelf.
Correct.
Subtracts “times the length” (4/5)and “times the width” (3/4)fractions in the bottom shelf bullet point from the correct length and width measurements of the middle shelf.
Uses the middle shelf length and width.

SubTopics: Demonstrate an understanding of multiplication as scaling (resizing).
Content: Two expressions are described below.
expression R: multiply 35 by 6/5
expression S: multiply 35 by 3/4
Based on the descriptions, which statement is true?

A.Choice: The value of expression R is greater than 35 because 6/5 < 1.

Key.Rationale: Uses the incorrect inequality.

B.Choice: The value of expression R is greater than 35 because 6/5 > 1.

Key.Rationale: Correct.

C.Choice: The value of expression S is greater than 35 because 3/4 < 1.

Key.Rationale: Uses the correct inequality for 3/4 but incorrectly states the effect of multiplying by a number less than 1.

D.Choice: The value of expression S is greater than 35 because 3/4 > 1.

Key.Rationale: Does not use the correct inequality (although the statement matches the inequality used).

SubTopics: Analyze and complete calculations by applying the order of operations.
Content: The value of the expression shown below is 7.5.
Each 2 in the expression is changed to a 3 to make a new expression. What is the difference in the values of the expressions?

Key.Rationale: Assumes the change in the value of the expression will be 1 because 2 was increased by 1.
Correct.
Increases the original value of the expression by 1 because 2 was increased by 1.
Multiplies 7.5 by 3.

SubTopics: Write simple expressions that model calculations with numbers and interpret numerical expressions without evaluating them.
Content: Which calculation is represented by the expression (5 + 2) ÷ 9?

A.Choice: divide five by nine, then add two

Key.Rationale: Confuses order of operations.

B.Choice: divide two by nine, then add five

Key.Rationale: Confuses order of operations.

C.Choice: divide the sum of five and two by nine

Key.Rationale: Correct.

D.Choice: divide nine by the sum of five and two

Key.Rationale: Reverses division.

SubTopics: Create, extend, and analyze patterns.
Content: The four shapes shown below repeat to form a pattern.
problems/PA19G5M/media/12a.jpg
The pattern continues. What is the 67th shape in the pattern?

Key.Rationale: Chooses 1 more instead of 1 less than a “complete” pattern (multiple of 4).
Selects the 66th shape.
Correct.
Selects the 68th shape (or 67 after the first).

SubTopics: Convert between different-sized measurement units within a given measurement system.

Apply the formulas V = l × w × h and V = B × h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole-number edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A company uses boxes with the dimensions shown below. The width is in inches. The length and height are in feet.
problems/PA19G5M/media/13a.jpg
What is the volume, in cubic inches, of each box?

Key.Rationale: Does not convert any of the measurements.
Only converts one side to inches, and evaluates 12 × 6 × 1.
Uses 10 inches to equal 1 foot.
Correct.

SubTopics: Solve problems involving computation of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Content: The line plot below shows the number of hours Mr. Jacobson spent writing for each of the last nine days.
problems/PA19G5M/media/14a.jpg
What is the total number of hours Mr. Jacobson spent writing over the last nine days?

Key.Rationale: Adds only the whole numbers.
Adds the numerators and denominators in all the fractions.
Correct.
Incorrectly combines the fractional parts of the 4 greatest values to get 2 instead of 1 + 3/4.

SubTopics: Display and interpret data shown in tallies, tables, charts, pictographs, bar graphs, and line graphs, and use a title, appropriate scale, and labels. A grid will be provided to display data on bar graphs or line graphs.
Content: A bar graph is shown below, but some of the information is missing.
problems/PA19G5M/media/15a.jpg
Which title and axis labels would be most appropriate for the graph?

A.Choice:
Title: Leo’s Plants 
 A: Type of Plant 
 B: Average Height (inches)

Key.Rationale: Selects title and axis labels that would work if labels were switched.

B.Choice:
Title: Airplane Elevation 
 A: Elevation (feet) 
 B: Time since Start (minutes)

Key.Rationale: Does not recognize the non-continuous aspect of the x-axis.

C.Choice:
Title: Voting Results 
 A: Number of Voters 
 B: Candidate

Key.Rationale: Correct.

D.Choice:
Title: Movie Tickets 
 A: Number of Tickets 
 B: Total Cost ($)

Key.Rationale: Does not recognize the non-continuous aspect of the x-axis.

SubTopics: Use, describe, and develop procedures to solve problems involving volume.
Content: The bottom of the rectangular prism shown below is covered by 1-inch cubes.
problems/PA19G5M/media/16a.jpg
The height of the prism is 3 inches. Which statement explains how to determine the volume, in cubic inches, of the rectangular prism?

A.Choice: Add two more layers of the number of cubes in the bottom layer: 15 + 15 + 15.

Key.Rationale: Correct.

B.Choice: Multiply the number of cubes in the bottom layer two more times: 15 × 15 × 15.

Key.Rationale: Confuses multiplication with addition.

C.Choice: Add 3 to the number of cubes in the length and width of the bottom layer: 3 + 5 + 3.

Key.Rationale: Confuses adding layers with adding to the dimensions.

D.Choice: Multiply the number of cubes in the bottom layer by the length and width of the bottom layer: 15 × 5 × 3.

Key.Rationale: Mixes adding layers with multiplying dimensions.
